question:
Select the most appropriate option to substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Rohan exercised and ate a lot, l̲e̲s̲t̲ ̲h̲e̲ ̲s̲h̲o̲u̲l̲d̲ ̲n̲o̲t̲ ̲b̲e̲ ̲w̲e̲a̲k̲ .

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 18-Sep Shift 2)
option_1: lest he should be weak
option_2: lest he should not weak
option_3: lest he would be weak
option_4: lest he would not be weak.
solution:
Correct Answer: lest he should be weak

Explanation:
The conjunction "lest" means to prevent something undesirable from happening and is always followed by a verb in the subjunctive mood, typically with "should". The phrase "lest he should not be weak" is incorrect because "lest" already conveys a negative meaning, so adding "not" creates a double negative.

Other Options:

  • lest he should not weak – Incorrect; "weak" is an adjective, so it needs a verb like "be" to make grammatical sense.

  • lest he would be weak – Incorrect; "would" is not used with "lest."

  • lest he would not be weak – Incorrect; contains both "would" (wrong with "lest") and "not" (double negative).

question:

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
N̲o̲ ̲s̲o̲o̲n̲e̲r̲ ̲a̲s̲ ̲I̲ ̲s̲a̲w̲ the boy running across the road, I applied the brakes.

solution:

"No sooner had + subject + past participle + than..."

But in this sentence, the phrase is incorrectly written as:

"No sooner as I saw..." – which is grammatically incorrect.

Now let's evaluate the options:

  • Option 1: "As soon as I saw" – This is correct and makes the sentence grammatically and contextually sound:

"As soon as I saw the boy running across the road, I applied the brakes."

  • Option 2: "No improvement required" – Incorrect; the current structure is flawed.

  • Option 3: "No soon as I saw" – Grammatically incorrect; “No soon” is never used.

question:

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
John was absent from the meeting because he was sick, ̲n̲o̲r̲ ̲d̲i̲d̲ ̲h̲e̲ ̲i̲n̲f̲o̲r̲m̲ ̲a̲n̲y̲o̲n̲e̲.̲

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
option_1: and did not he inform anyone
option_2: nor did he informed anyone
option_4: but he did not inform anyone
solution:
The sentence uses the phrase "nor did he inform anyone", which is grammatically correct. However, we must check if there’s a more appropriate or natural construction.

  • The sentence begins with a reason clause: “John was absent from the meeting because he was sick...”

  • Then it adds additional information: that he also didn’t inform anyone.

Now let’s evaluate the options:

  • "and did not he inform anyone" – Incorrect word order (should be “he did not,” not “did not he”).

  • "nor did he informed anyone" – Incorrect verb form after “did” (should be “inform,” not “informed”).

  • "No improvement required" – The use of “nor” is slightly awkward here because the clause is not preceded by a negative that “nor” builds on.

  • "but he did not inform anyone" – This is the most natural and grammatically sound improvement. It smoothly contrasts the cause of his absence with his failure to notify others.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
The car turned upside down n̲o̲ ̲s̲o̲o̲n̲e̲r̲ ̲a̲s̲ ̲i̲t̲ ̲h̲i̲t̲ the light pole.

option_1: no sooner than it had hit
option_3: as soon as it hit
option_4: no soon as it hit
solution:
Solution:

  • The original sentence:
    "The car turned upside down no sooner as it hit the light pole."

  • The phrase "no sooner" is part of a correlative construction that must be followed by "than", not "as".

  • The correct structure is:
    "No sooner + past perfect + than + past simple"
    But since the sentence is in simple past, the closest grammatically and stylistically correct substitute is:
    "as soon as it hit" – a simpler and appropriate alternative.

  • So, the improved sentence becomes:
    "The car turned upside down as soon as it hit the light pole."

  • Why other options are incorrect:

  • Option 1: "no sooner than it had hit" – incorrect word order and tense usage.

  • Option 2: "No improvement required" – incorrect because "no sooner as" is grammatically wrong.

  • Option 4: "no soon as it hit" – grammatically incorrect phrase.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select ‘No improvement required’.
October has four consecutive holidays b̲u̲t̲ ̲w̲e̲ ̲a̲r̲e̲ ̲p̲l̲a̲n̲n̲i̲n̲g̲ a trip to Andaman Islands

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
solution:
Solution:

    "October has four consecutive holidays but we are planning a trip to Andaman Islands."

  • The conjunction "but" implies contrast, which does not fit the context here.

  • The second part of the sentence is a result or natural action due to the first part (i.e., because there are holidays, a trip is being planned).
    So, a cause-effect connector like "so" is more appropriate.

  • Corrected sentence:
    "October has four consecutive holidays, so we are planning a trip to Andaman Islands."

  • Why other options are incorrect:

  • "since we have planned" – changes the meaning and tense.

  • "because we are planning" – incorrect logical flow; cause and effect are reversed.

  • "No improvement required" – incorrect because "but" doesn’t convey the intended meaning.

Correct answer:
so we are planning (Option 3)

question:

question:
Select the option that will most suitably substitute the underlined part of the given sentence.
I gave my best dress to her o̲n̲ ̲c̲o̲n̲d̲i̲t̲i̲o̲n̲ ̲t̲h̲a̲t̲ ̲s̲h̲e̲ ̲r̲e̲t̲u̲r̲n̲ it the very next day in a clean condition.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (04-July Shift 2))
option_1: on the condition that she return
option_2: on the conditions that she had return
option_3: on the condition that she would return
option_4: on condition that she returned
solution:
Answer: 3 (on the condition that she would return)

Explanation:

  • The phrase "on condition that" or "on the condition that" can be followed by either the subjunctive mood (base verb: "return") or by "would" + verb in reported speech or informal contexts.

  • Option 1: "on the condition that she return" is grammatically correct (subjunctive), but sounds formal and may be less common in conversational English.

  • Option 3: "on the condition that she would return" is more natural in everyday usage when talking about future expectations.

  • Option 2 is incorrect because "conditions" should be singular and "had return" is grammatically wrong.

  • Option 4 is incorrect because "returned" in past tense doesn’t fit the meaning of the sentence expecting a future action.

Between options 1 and 3, option 3 fits better here for natural usage.

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can substitute the underlined segment in the given sentence. If there is no need to substitute it, select ‘No substitution required’.
He asked his father when w̲o̲u̲l̲d̲ ̲c̲o̲m̲e̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲n̲e̲x̲t̲ ̲l̲e̲t̲t̲e̲r̲.

option_2: would the next letter come
option_3: the next letter would come
solution:
Correct Answer:the next letter would come

Explanation:

The sentence is in indirect (reported) speech, so the word order must follow statement structure, not question structure.

Original sentence:
“He asked his father when would come the next letter.” – ❌ incorrect word order.

Correct reported speech structure:
Subject + would + base verb → “when the next letter would come.”

Let’s evaluate the options:

  • No substitution required – ❌ incorrect structure.

  • Would the next letter come – ❌ this is direct question word order; not suitable for reported speech.

  • The next letter would come – ✅ correct indirect speech structure.

  • Come the next letter – ❌ grammatically incorrect.

✅ Therefore, the correct substitution is: “the next letter would come.”

question:

The phrase "lest we make errors" means to avoid making errors and is the correct formal conjunction used to express purpose or prevention.

question:

question:

question:
Select the grammatically correct sentence from the options given.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.21_16-Oct_Shift-1)
option_1: Neither a boy nor a mother could identify the man.
option_2: Neither the boy nor the mother could identify the man.
option_3: Neither a boy nor the mother could identify a man.
option_4: Neither the boy nor a mother could identify a man.
solution:
Answer: Neither the boy nor the mother could identify the man.

Explanation:
This sentence is grammatically correct and clear in structure. The rules followed here are:

  • “Neither...nor...” is a correlative conjunction pair and must be followed by grammatically parallel elements.

  • Using “the boy” and “the mother” maintains parallelism — both are specific and definite.

  • The object “the man” is also specific and aligns with the rest of the sentence.

Other options have mismatched or indefinite articles:

  • “a boy” and “the mother” – inconsistent use of articles.

  • “a man” as object implies any man, which feels vague compared to the definite subject.

  • Mixing “a mother” and “the boy” lacks parallelism in specificity.

Thus, the most balanced and grammatically correct sentence is:
"Neither the boy nor the mother could identify the man."

question:
Select the most appropriate option that can replace the underlined segment in the given sentence.

  • their home that it start – ❌ Wrong connector and incorrect verb tense

question:

N̲o̲ ̲s̲o̲o̲n̲e̲r̲ ̲h̲a̲d̲ ̲s̲h̲e̲ ̲e̲n̲t̲e̲r̲ ̲h̲e̲r̲ ̲a̲p̲a̲r̲t̲m̲e̲n̲t̲ ̲t̲h̲a̲n̲ she found a bouquet of flowers on her table.

  • In English, the construction “hardly… when” indicates that one action immediately follows another: “Hardly had she heard the news when she began to weep.”

  • than is used for comparisons, well and while don’t express this rapid sequence.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to replace the underlined segment in the given sentence.
Shyama does not laugh, n̲o̲r̲ ̲s̲h̲e̲ ̲s̲m̲i̲l̲e̲s̲.̲

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 8 Dec Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: nor does she smile

Explanation:
The correlative conjunction nor requires subject–auxiliary inversion when following a negative clause. After “does not laugh,” it should be:

  • nor + auxiliary (“does”) + subject (“she”) + base verb (“smile”).

  • Correct: “Shyama does not laugh, nor does she smile.”

  • Incorrect word orders fail to invert the auxiliary and subject.
